d2sqlite3

Simple SQLite interface.

This module provides a simple "object-oriented" interface to the SQLite database engine.

Objects in this interface (Database and Query) automatically create the SQLite objects they need. They are reference-counted, so that when their last reference goes out of scope, the underlying SQLite objects are automatically closed and finalized. They are not thread-safe.

Usage:
  1. Create a Database object, providing the path of the database file (or an empty path, or the reserved path ":memory:").
  2. Execute SQL code according to your need:
    • If you don't need parameter binding, create a Query object with a single SQL statement and either use Query.execute() if you don't expect the query to return rows, or use Query.rows() directly in the other case.
    • If you need parameter binding, create a Query object with a single SQL statement that includes binding names, and use Parameter methods as many times as necessary to bind all values. Then either use Query.execute() if you don't expect the query to return rows, or use Query.rows() directly in the other case.
    • If you don't need parameter bindings and if you can ignore the rows that the query could return, you can use the facility function Database.execute(). In this case, more than one statements can be run in one call, as long as they are separated by semi-colons.
See example in the documentation for the Database struct below.

The C API is available through etc.c.sqlite3.

License:
Boost License 1.0.

Authors:
Nicolas Sicard (dransic@gmail.com).

struct Sqlite3;
Metadata from the SQLite library.

static @property string versionString();
Gets the library's version string (e.g. 3.6.12).

static @property int versionNumber();
Gets the library's version number (e.g. 3006012).

enum SharedCache: bool;
Use of a shared cache.

See http://www.sqlite.org/sharedcache.html

enabled
Shared cache is enabled.

disabled
Shared cache is disabled (the default in SQLite).

struct Database;
An interface to a SQLite database connection.

Examples:
// Open a database in memory.
Database db;
try
{
    db = Database(":memory:");
}
catch (SqliteException e)
{
    // Error creating the database
    assert(false, "Error: " ~ e.msg);
}

// Create a table.
try
{
    db.execute(
        "CREATE TABLE person (
            id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
            last_name TEXT NOT NULL,
            first_name TEXT,
            score REAL,
            photo BLOB
         )"
    );
}
catch (SqliteException e)
{
    // Error creating the table.
    assert(false, "Error: " ~ e.msg);
}

// Populate the table.
try
{
    auto query = db.query(
        "INSERT INTO person (last_name, first_name, score, photo)
         VALUES (:last_name, :first_name, :score, :photo)"
    );
    
    // Bind everything with chained calls to params.bind().
    query.bind(":last_name", "Smith");
    query.bind(":first_name", "John");
    query.bind(":score", 77.5);
    ubyte[] photo = cast(ubyte[]) "..."; // Store the photo as raw array of data.
    query.bind(":photo", photo);
    query.execute();
    
    query.reset(); // Need to reset the query after execution.
    query.bind(":last_name", "Doe");
    query.bind(":first_name", "John");
    query.bind(3, null); // Use of index instead of name.
    query.bind(":photo", null);
    query.execute();
}
catch (SqliteException e)
{
    // Error executing the query.
    assert(false, "Error: " ~ e.msg);
}
assert(db.totalChanges == 2); // Two 'persons' were inserted.

// Reading the table
try
{
    // Count the Johns in the table.
    auto query = db.query("SELECT count(*) FROM person WHERE first_name == 'John'");
    assert(query.rows.front[0].get!int() == 2);
    
    // Fetch the data from the table.
    query = db.query("SELECT * FROM person");
    foreach (row; query.rows)
    {
        // "id" should be the column at index 0:
        auto id = row[0].get!int();
        // Some conversions are possible with the method as():
        auto name = format("%s, %s", row["last_name"].get!string(), row["first_name"].get!(char[])());
        // The score can be NULL, so provide 0 (instead of NAN) as a default value to replace NULLs:
        auto score = row["score"].get!real(0.0);
        // Use opDispatch to retrieve a column from its name
        auto photo = row.photo.get!(ubyte[])();
        
        // ... and use all these data!
    }
}
catch (SqliteException e)
{
    // Error reading the database.
    assert(false, "Error: " ~ e.msg);
}


this(string path, int flags = SQLITE_OPEN_READWRITE | SQLITE_OPEN_CREATE, string vfs = null);
Opens a database connection.

The database is open using the sqlite3_open_v2 function. See http://www.sqlite.org/c3ref/open.html to know how to use the flags or vfs parameters, or to use path as a file URI if the current configuration allows it.

deprecated this(string path, SharedCache sharedCache);
Opens a database connection.

Deprecated:
Use the constructor that takes sqlite3_open_v2 arguments or set the path as a file URI (v3.7.7+) and set the URI to e.g. "file:path?cache=shared".

void close();
Explicitly closes the database.

Throws an SqliteException if the database cannot be closed.

After this function has been called successfully, using this databse object or a query depending on it is a programming error.

void execute(string sql);
Execute the given SQL code.

Rows returned by any statements are ignored.

Query query(string sql);
Creates a query on the database and returns it.

@property int changes();
Gets the number of database rows that were changed, inserted or deleted by the most recently completed query.

@property int totalChanges();
Gets the number of database rows that were changed, inserted or deleted since the database was opened.

@property int errorCode();
Gets the SQLite error code of the last operation.

@property string errorMsg();
Gets the SQLite error message of the last operation.

@property sqlite3* handle();
Gets the SQLite internal handle of the database connection.

void createAggregate(Aggregate, string name = Aggregate.stringof)();
Creates and registers a new aggregate function in the database.

The type Aggregate must be a struct that implements at least these two methods: accumulate and result, and that must be default-constructible.

See also: http://www.sqlite.org/lang_aggfunc.html

Examples:
struct weighted_average
{
    double total_value = 0.0;
    double total_weight = 0.0;

    void accumulate(double value, double weight)
    {
        total_value += value * weight;
        total_weight += weight;
    }

    double result()
    {
        return total_value / total_weight;
    }
}

auto db = Database(":memory:");
db.execute("CREATE TABLE test (value FLOAT, weight FLOAT)");
db.createAggregate!(weighted_average, "w_avg")();

auto query = db.query("INSERT INTO test (value, weight) VALUES (:v, :w)");
double[double] list = [11.5: 3, 14.8: 1.6, 19: 2.4];
foreach (value, weight; list) {
    query.bind(":v", value);
    query.bind(":w", weight);
    query.execute();
    query.reset();
}

query = db.query("SELECT w_avg(value, weight) FROM test");
import std.math: approxEqual;        
assert(approxEqual(query.oneValue!double, (11.5*3 + 14.8*1.6 + 19*2.4)/(3 + 1.6 + 2.4)));


void createCollation(alias fun, string name = __traits(identifier, fun))();
Creates and registers a collation function in the database.

The function fun must satisfy these criteria:
  • It must take two string arguments, e.g. s1 and s2.
  • Its return value ret must satisfy these criteria (when s3 is any other string):
    • If s1 is less than s2, ret < 0.
    • If s1 is equal to s2, ret == 0.
    • If s1 is greater than s2, ret > 0.
    • If s1 is equal to s2, then s2 is equal to s1.
    • If s1 is equal to s2 and s2 is equal to s3, then s1 is equal to s3.
    • If s1 is less than s2, then s2 is greater than s1.
    • If s1 is less than s2 and s2 is less than s3, then s1 is less than s3.


The function will have the name name in the database; this name defaults to the identifier of the function fun.

See also: http://www.sqlite.org/lang_aggfunc.html

Examples:
static int my_collation(string s1, string s2)
{
    import std.uni;
    return icmp(s1, s2);
}

auto db = Database(":memory:");
db.createCollation!my_collation();
db.execute("CREATE TABLE test (val TEXT)");

auto query = db.query("INSERT INTO test (val) VALUES (:val)");
query.bind(":val", "A");
query.execute();
query.reset();
query.bind(":val", "B");
query.execute();
query.reset();
query.bind(":val", "a");
query.execute();

query = db.query("SELECT val FROM test ORDER BY val COLLATE my_collation");
assert(query.rows.front[0].get!string() == "A");
query.rows.popFront();
assert(query.rows.front[0].get!string() == "a");
query.rows.popFront();
assert(query.rows.front[0].get!string() == "B");


void createFunction(alias fun, string name = __traits(identifier, fun))();
Creates and registers a simple function in the database.

The function fun must satisfy these criteria:
  • It must not be a variadic.
  • Its arguments must all have a type that is compatible with SQLite types: boolean, integral, floating point, string, or array of bytes (BLOB types).
  • Its return value must also be of a compatible type.


The function will have the name name in the database; this name defaults to the identifier of the function fun.

See also: http://www.sqlite.org/lang_corefunc.html

Examples:
static string test_args(bool b, int i, double d, string s, ubyte[] a)
{
    if (b && i == 42 && d == 4.2 && s == "42" && a == [0x04, 0x02])
        return "OK";
    else
        return "NOT OK";
}
static bool test_bool()
{
    return true;
}
static int test_int()
{
    return 42;
}
static double test_double()
{
    return 4.2;
}
static string test_string()
{
    return "42";
}
static immutable(ubyte)[] test_ubyte()
{
    return [0x04, 0x02];
}

auto db = Database(":memory:");
db.createFunction!test_args();
db.createFunction!test_bool();
db.createFunction!test_int();
db.createFunction!test_double();
db.createFunction!test_string();
db.createFunction!test_ubyte();
auto query = db.query("SELECT test_args(test_bool(), test_int(), test_double(), test_string(), test_ubyte())");
assert(query.rows.front[0].get!string() == "OK");


struct Query;
An interface to SQLite query execution.

deprecated @property ref Parameters params();
Gets the bindable parameters of the query.

The returned Parameters object becomes invalid when the Query goes out of scope.

Deprecated:
use Query.bind() directly.

void bind(T)(int index, T value);
void bind(T)(string name, T value);
Binds values to parameters in the query.

The index is the position of the parameter in the SQL query (starting from 0). The name must include the ':', '@' or '$' that introduces it in the query.

void clearBindings();
Clears the bindings.

This does not reset the prepared statement. Use Query.reset() for this.

void execute();
Executes the query.

Use rows() directly if the query is expected to return rows.

@property ref RowRange rows();
Gets the results of a query that returns rows as a input range of Row objects.

The range of rows can only be iterated once, and the rows cannot be copied. The range also becomes invalid when the Query goes out of scope.

@property auto oneValue(T)();
Gets only the first value of the first row returned by a query.

Examples:
auto db = Database(":memory:");
db.execute("CREATE TABLE test (val INTEGER)");
auto query = db.query("SELECT count(*) FROM test");
query.execute();
assert(query.oneValue!int == 0);


void reset();
Resets a query's prepared statement before a new execution.

This does not clear the bindings. Use Parameters.clear() for this.

@property sqlite3_stmt* statement();
Gets the SQLite internal handle of the query statement.

struct Parameters;
The bound parameters of a query.

Deprecated:
kept only for compatibility. Use the corresponding methods of Query.

ref Parameters bind(T)(int index, T value);
ref Parameters bind(T)(string name, T value);
Binds values to parameters in the query.

The index is the position of the parameter in the SQL query (starting from 0). The name must include the ':', '@' or '$' that introduces it in the query.

@property int length();
Gets the number of parameters.

void clear();
Clears the bindings.

This does not reset the prepared statement. Use Query.reset() for this.

struct Row;
A SQLite row, implemented as a random-access range of Column objects.

@property bool empty();
@property Column front();
void popFront();
Input range primitives

@property Row save();
Forward range primitive

@property Column back();
void popBack();
Bidirectional range primitives

@property size_t length();
Column opIndex(size_t index);
Random access range primitives

Column opIndex(string name);
@property Column opDispatch(string name)();
Returns a column based on its name.

The names of the statements' columns are checked each time this function is called: use numeric indexing for better performance.

struct Column;
A SQLite column.

T get(T)(T defaultValue = T.init);
Gets the value of the column converted to type T. If the value is NULL, it is replaced by defaultValue.

T can be a boolean, a numeric type, a string, an array or a Variant.

@property int type();
Gets the type of the column.

string literal(T)(T value);
Turns a value into a literal that can be used in an SQLite expression.

Examples:
assert(null.literal == "NULL");
assert(false.literal == "0");
assert(true.literal == "1");
assert(4.literal == "4");
assert(4.1.literal == "4.1");
assert("foo".literal == "'foo'");
assert("a'b'".literal == "'a''b'''");
auto a = cast(ubyte[]) x"DEADBEEF";
assert(a.literal == "'XDEADBEEF'");


class SqliteException: object.Exception;
Exception thrown when SQLite functions return an error.
